questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with acute right-flank pain that radiates to the ipsilateral groin, accompanied by nocturia and polyuria. He has a history of gout, lower back pain, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He has been taking over-the-counter oral antacids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medicines, and acetaminophen regularly for several years.
His blood pressure is 137/85 mm Hg, his heart rate is 87 beats per minute, and his temperature is 36.7°C. The physical examination is within normal limits, except for tenderness to percussion over the right flank.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8000
4500–11,000


Sodium (mEq/liter)
136
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.3
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
109
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
20
21–30



Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.1
0.8–1.3


His fasting plasma glucose level is normal. His urinalysis shows 4 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), 20 red cells per high-power field (0–2), no bacteria, and a urine protein-to-creatinine ratio of 1.3 mg/mg (<0.2). A CT scan of the abdomen shows irregular contours of the kidneys with papillary calcifications.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Analgesic nephropathy is caused by long-term use of analgesic agents and is characterized by papillary necrosis and chronic interstitial nephritis with hematuria and mild sterile pyuria on urinalysis. CT of the kidneys without contrast is useful to diagnose analgesic nephropathy. The earliest finding is evidence of papillary necrosis with calcifications in the renal papilla; subsequently, kidneys may have irregular contours or reduced size.

Analgesic nephropathy may occur after years of taking large doses of analgesics, alone or in combination. Implicated agents include nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, aspirin, phenacetin, acetaminophen, codeine, and caffeine. The risk for analgesic nephrotoxicity appears to be dose-dependent and increases significantly once the patient has ingested a cumulative dose greater than 3 kg.

Most patients are asymptomatic, but flank pain, hematuria, and even obstruction may occur from papillary necrosis. Proteinuria is typically mild in patients with analgesic nephropathy, and patients may have a urinary concentrating defect. Hypertension and anemia are common as well. The renal biopsy is characterized by chronic interstitial nephritis, most markedly in the medulla and papillary necrosis.

Key learning point: The classic finding seen on CT of the kidneys in analgesic nephropathy is evidence of papillary calcifications.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis may cause renal colic, but it does not acutely cause proteinuria or a decline in renal function (although this can be seen if the kidney stones are causing chronic injury to the renal parenchyma). Acute obstruction of one kidney should not cause a doubling of the serum creatinine level unless there is underlying renal dysfunction. Additionally, the imaging findings in this case are not consistent with nephrolithiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis is typically characterized by fever and leukocytosis. The CT findings seen in this case are not consistent with pyelonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute interstitial nephritis does not cause sudden unilateral pain, nor does it cause irregular contours of the kidney.

E) INCORRECT:

Uric acid nephrolithiasis may cause renal colic, but it does not acutely cause proteinuria or a decline in renal function (although this can be seen if the kidney stones are causing chronic injury to the renal parenchyma). Acute obstruction of one kidney should not cause a doubling of the serum creatinine level unless there is underlying renal dysfunction. Additionally, the imaging findings in this case are not consistent with nephrolithiasis.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman is hospitalized for evaluation of gross hematuria and abnormal kidney function. She has had four episodes of gross hematuria lasting 1 to 2 days each during the past year. The episodes do not occur at the same time as her menses. Each time, she was treated with a 3-day course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for presumed urinary tract infection. Six months ago, her serum creatinine level was 1.4 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1). She has no family history of kidney disease.
On examination, she is afebrile. Her blood pressure is 154/96 mm Hg, her heart rate is 82 beats per minute, and her weight is 68 kg. There is mild, pitting bilateral lower-extremity edema, but the remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.
Current laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.8
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
159,000
150,000–350,000



Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.4
0.6–1.1


Her urine dipstick shows 3+ protein and 3+ blood. Her urine sediment shows 51 to 100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2).
An ultrasound reveals kidneys that are normal in size; there is no hydronephrosis.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Doppler studies of the renal veins

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hematuria — gross, as in this case, or microscopic — can be caused by bleeding anywhere in the urinary tract from the glomeruli to the urethra. Therefore, the differential diagnosis is broad and includes glomerular disease, nephrolithiasis, urologic malignancy, renal papillary necrosis, prostate disorders, acute trauma, infection, hematologic disorders, and other forms of cystitis. Radiation to the pelvis may produce hemorrhagic cystitis, and patients who are excessively anticoagulated may develop hematuria without identifiable structural disease. Abdominal aortic dissection may have associated hematuria due to renal ischemia.

This patient has proteinuria and progressive chronic kidney disease in addition to gross hematuria. Taken together, these findings suggest glomerular disease. Definitive diagnosis of glomerular hematuria is obtained only by kidney biopsy and will help guide therapy.

In patients with gross nonglomerular hematuria, it is appropriate to evaluate the upper urinary tract (with a CT urogram) and lower urinary tract (with cystoscopy) for causes of hematuria.

In cases of incidentally noted microscopic nonglomerular hematuria, the evaluation is based on an assessment of the risk for urothelial cancer. Risk factors for urothelial cancer include age ≥50 in women and ≥40 in men, cigarette smoking (50% of cases), chemical exposures, drug exposures (cyclophosphamide, phenacetin), radiation, chronic urinary stone disease, chronic catheterization, chronic infections, and genetic mutations. In the presence of risk factors, patients with microscopic nonglomerular hematuria should undergo evaluation of the upper and lower urinary tract with CT urogram (or renal ultrasound in immediate-risk patients) and cystoscopy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to diagnose the cause of abnormal kidney function, proteinuria, and intermittent gross hematuria is kidney biopsy.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
β-hCG: beta-human chorionic gonadotropin
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
HPF: high-power field
RBC: red blood cell
UA: urinalysis
US: ultrasound
UTI: urinary tract infection

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with gross nonglomerular hematuria, it is appropriate to evaluate the upper urinary tract (with a CT urogram) and lower urinary tract (with cystoscopy) for causes of hematuria. In the presence of risk factors, patients with microscopic nonglomerular hematuria should undergo evaluation of the upper and lower urinary tract with CT urogram (or renal ultrasound in immediate-risk patients) and cystoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology was previously recommended to evaluate the lower tract in patients at low risk for bladder cancer, but it is an insensitive study. Furthermore, malignancies that cause hematuria are not generally associated with proteinuria or a significant decline in renal function.

D) INCORRECT:

Doppler studies of the renal veins are used to detect renal-vein thrombosis. This entity is more common in the setting of nephrotic syndrome with heavy proteinuria or a hypercoaguable state from a malignancy. Patients may be asymptomatic or report flank pain. If there has been a thrombosis of one renal vein, this would not explain the rise in serum creatinine to the degree seen in this patient. Instead, causes of glomerular bleeding should be pursued.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with gross nonglomerular hematuria, it is appropriate to evaluate the upper urinary tract (with a CT urogram) and lower urinary tract (with cystoscopy) for causes of hematuria.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man is seen for his second episode of painless gross hematuria within the past 10 days. Between episodes, he is asymptomatic, and his urine is odorless and normal in color. He has been otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He smoked cigarettes for 35 years and quit 5 years ago. His physical examination is unremarkable.
His serum creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3). Urinalysis reveals pink urine. Urine microscopy reveals >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), with no casts or dysmorphic red cells.
In addition to referral for cystoscopy, which one of the following imaging studies is most appropriate?

choices.text: Radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis
MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis would provide little information; it will not visualize tumors or radiolucent stones.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography is good for detecting medullary sponge kidney and large renal masses and was historically used for the evaluation of hematuria, but it has been replaced by the excretory phase of the CT urogram. Intravenous pyelography has a much lower sensitivity for renal masses smaller than 2 to 3 cm and can miss peripheral lesions.

C) CORRECT:

Hematuria can occur from glomerular diseases or structural abnormalities of the urinary tract, including renal-cell carcinoma, urothelial malignancy, urolithiasis, or papillary necrosis.

All patients who have visible or gross hematuria without a clear cause should undergo evaluation of the upper urinary tract, by imaging and evaluation of the lower urinary tract by cystoscopy, to determine the source of hematuria and exclude malignancy. The evaluation of microscopic nonglomerular hematuria is more complex and is determined, in part, by risk factors such as age, history of smoking, and exposure to potential carcinogens.

The single best imaging study to evaluate the source of hematuria in the upper urinary tract is CT urography. Without contrast, CT urography will identify kidney stones of every type; with contrast, it can detect even small lesions in the cortex of the kidney.

Key learning point: All patients with unexplained gross hematuria should have an evaluation to exclude malignancy that includes cystoscopy and CT urography.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
β-hCG: beta-human chorionic gonadotropin
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
HPF: high-power field
RBC: red blood cell
UA: urinalysis
US: ultrasound
UTI: urinary tract infection

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the abdomen and pelvis is not recommended as a first-line study in this case because its sensitivity and specificity have not been well studied. Nevertheless, it can be used as an aid to further characterize known lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

A retroperitoneal ultrasound to assess kidney size and echogenicity could be appropriate if there were evidence of a glomerular source of hematuria. Ultrasound can detect kidney stones in the renal pelvis and can also distinguish cystic from solid masses, but it can miss small lesions and kidney stones in the ureter. This modality can play a useful role in individuals who cannot tolerate contrast (as in chronic kidney disease) or radiation exposure (as in pregnancy).

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman with a history of cigarette smoking (40 pack-years), mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents for follow-up evaluation 4 weeks after an episode of gross hematuria.
During the initial episode, urinalysis with microscopy revealed >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), 20 to 30 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and occasional bacteria. She was given a 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
Today, the patient reports no further episodes of gross hematuria, and she states she does not experience any dysuria or flank pain. Urinalysis reveals 40 to 50 red cells per high-power field, and urine culture is negative. Her urine protein-to-creatinine ratio is 0.1 mg/mg (reference range, <0.2).
Serum laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.5
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5000
4500–11,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.6–1.1


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.2
9.0–10.5


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
12
10–20


In addition to cystoscopy, which one of the following tests is most appropriate for evaluating this patient?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast
CT urography with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephrology referral for hematuria is reasonable in patients who appear to have a glomerular cause of their hematuria (albuminuria, dysmorphic red cells, red-cell casts, elevated serum creatinine, or new or worsening hypertension or edema) or in patients whose hematuria is unexplained. Such a referral would be premature for this patient at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

CT without contrast would be helpful for diagnosing kidney stones but could miss important lesions in the kidney.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasonography is not the preferred mode of evaluation for patients with normal renal function (as in this case) because it is not sufficiently sensitive to detect neoplasms <3 cm. It is a reasonable alternative, however, for patients with reduced renal function, given that it does not require contrast.

D) INCORRECT:

In young patients with incidental microscopic nonglomerular hematuria and no risk factors for urothelial cancer (e.g., cigarette smoking), a repeat urinalysis may be sufficient. This patient requires further workup.

E) CORRECT:

Even a single episode of painless gross hematuria or asymptomatic microscopic hematuria (defined as ≥3 red cells per high-power field on microscopic analysis) requires further evaluation. Hematuria can originate from a glomerular source or a nonglomerular source. A glomerular source is more likely when there is proteinuria, dysmorphic red cells, or cellular casts. This patient has no features to suggest a glomerular source. Therefore, the patient should be evaluated for causes of bleeding from the upper urinary tract (neoplasm, nephrolithiasis, or cystic disease) or the lower urinary tract (bladder, urethra, or [in men] prostate).

All patients with gross (visible) nonglomerular hematuria without an obvious explanation should undergo an evaluation with cystoscopy and a radiologic evaluation of the upper urinary tract, typically CT urography. Patients without a history of gross hematuria in whom incidental microscopic nonglomerular hematuria is noted should undergo a similar evaluation if risk factors for urothelial cancer are present, such as age ≥50 for women, age ≥40 for men, cigarette smoking, or relevant chemical exposures. In younger, lower-risk patients, a repeat urinalysis in 6 months may be sufficient with further evaluation only if the microscopic hematuria persists.

CT urography with and without contrast is now considered the gold standard in evaluating upper urinary tract causes of hematuria. Imaging done without contrast can detect kidney stones of every variety, whereas imaging done with contrast can detect small parenchymal lesions that could be missed by ultrasound, a CT without contrast, or an intravenous pyelogram.

Urine cytology identifies most high-grade lesions but is not sensitive enough to detect uroepithelial cancer and is therefore not recommended in the evaluation of hematuria. Although treatment for a urinary tract infection at the onset of this patient’s illness was reasonable, the lack of symptoms to support a urinary tract infection makes it an unlikely cause of the hematuria, and a repeat urine culture is unlikely to explain the ongoing hematuria.

Key learning point: All patients with unexplained gross hematuria should have an evaluation to exclude malignancy that includes cystoscopy and CT urography with and without contrast.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
β-hCG: beta-human chorionic gonadotropin
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
HPF: high-power field
RBC: red blood cell
UA: urinalysis
US: ultrasound
UTI: urinary tract infection

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is seen for follow-up of microscopic hematuria. Her medical history is significant only for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation diagnosed 6 months ago, for which she takes dabigatran. She smoked cigarettes for 20 years but has no chemical exposures and takes no medications besides dabigatran. She has no urological symptoms or other complaints.
Her vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. Laboratory tests last week were within normal limits, including a serum creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1).
Repeat urinalysis reveals 7 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and one white cell per high-power field (0–2), with no dysmorphic red cells or red-cell casts. Her urine protein-to-creatinine ratio is 0.08 mg/mg (reference range, <0.2). A kidney ultrasound shows no abnormalities.
In addition to cystoscopy, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast
Monitoring with annual urinalysis for at least 2 years
Repeat kidney ultrasound in 3 to 6 months
CT urography with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retrograde pyelography is an invasive study that is used to evaluate upper tract abnormalities seen on CT or in patients who cannot undergo CT or MRI (e.g., because of contrast allergy or a pacemaker).

B) INCORRECT:

CT without contrast can detect all types of kidney stones and is appropriate if the clinical history is consistent with nephrolithiasis, but it is not sufficiently sensitive to detect small urothelial lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic microhematuria in the setting of anticoagulation use still requires a comprehensive evaluation, because a substantial proportion of these patients are found to have urothelial cancer. Performing annual urinalysis alone is therefore inappropriate without first completing imaging to evaluate the upper urinary tract and cystoscopy to evaluate the lower urinary tract.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the patient has already had a renal ultrasound, this would not have been a recommended test based on current guidelines, because ultrasonography can miss renal parenchymal tumors that are <3 cm.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has microhematuria, defined as ≥ 3 red cells per high-power field on microscopic evaluation of a properly collected sample. Only a single sample is needed to make this diagnosis, although it was confirmed on a second urinalysis in this case. Of note, a positive result for hemoglobin or red cells on dipstick of the urine should not be used to make this diagnosis. In the absence of microscopy findings to suggest a glomerular source of bleeding (such as dysmorphic red cells or red-cell casts) and without an obvious gynecologic or nonmalignant etiology for the hematuria (e.g., nephrolithiasis or a urinary tract infection), urothelial cancer needs to be excluded.

Current guidelines recommend stratifying patients with microhematuria by their risk for urothelial cancer and evaluating the patient based on their risk level:

Low Risk (all of the following criteria met):

• Age < 60 years in women, < 40 years in men
• Never smoker or smoking history of < 10 pack-years
• 3 to 10 red cells per high-power field
• No additional risk factors for urothelial cancer (such as certain chemical exposures, family history of urothelial cancer or Lynch syndrome, chronic indwelling foreign body in the urinary tract, or prior pelvic radiation therapy)

Low-risk patients should repeat urinalysis within 6 months. Persistent microhematuria on repeat urinalysis is reclassified as intermediate risk or high risk, which requires additional evaluation.

Intermediate Risk (any one of the following criteria met):

• Age ≥ 60 years in women, 40 to 59 years in men
• Smoking history of 10 to 30 pack-years
• 11 to 25 red cells per high-power field
• Presence of ≥ 1 risk factors for urinary tract cancer

Intermediate-risk patients should undergo cystoscopy and renal ultrasound.

High Risk (any one of the following criteria met):

• Age ≥ 60 years in men; women are not considered high risk based solely on age
• Smoking history of > 30 pack-years
• > 25 red cells per high-power field
• History of gross hematuria
• Presence of ≥ 1 risk factors for urinary tract cancer and any high-risk feature for urinary tract cancer

High-risk patients should undergo cystoscopy and CT urography.

Determining Risk and Next Steps in This Case

This patient falls into the high-risk category because of her age; her history of cigarette smoking is an additional risk factor. She should therefore undergo cystoscopy and CT urography.

Although the patient has already had a renal ultrasound, this would not have been a recommended test based on current guidelines, because ultrasonography can miss renal parenchymal tumors that are <3 cm.

Urine cytology, although often performed in practice, is not recommended in the initial evaluation of patients with microhematuria. Its sensitivity in detecting bladder cancer (66% to 79%) is lower than that of cystoscopy; thus, the additional benefit of detecting urothelial cancer in patients who have had cystoscopy and CT urography is minimal. There may be some benefit of urine cytology in patients who have urothelial carcinoma in situ, which can be difficult to visualize on cystoscopy. Therefore, guidelines recommend obtaining urine cytology in patients who have persistent microhematuria with irritative voiding symptoms or other risk factors for carcinoma in situ in whom CT urography and cystoscopy were normal.

Key learning point: The first steps in the diagnostic evaluation of a patient with nonglomerular microhematuria who is >60 years of age are cystoscopy and CT urography with and without contrast.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after a fall from the top level of a bunk bed. He complains of left flank pain and nausea. He has no significant medical history or allergies, and he takes no medications.
The patient is afebrile, his heart rate is 130 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, and his other vital signs are normal. He is alert and oriented, answering questions appropriately.
Focused assessment with sonography for trauma reveals no obvious fluid in the pelvis or in the perihepatic, perisplenic, or pericardial spaces.
Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria.
In addition to stabilizing the cervical spine, obtaining intravenous access, and performing a type and screen blood test, which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of aminotransferase levels and hematocrit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal radiographs are insufficient to rule out intra-abdominal injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Bladder injury is almost always associated with gross hematuria and also accompanied by suprapubic pain or an inability to urinate. A retrograde cystogram is the only study that can definitively diagnose a ruptured bladder; in males, if urethral injury is suspected, a retrograde urethrogram should be considered before placing a urethral catheter.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient who has sustained a trauma, initial evaluation and resuscitation should occur simultaneously. Despite this child’s negative results on focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST), which has good specificity but variable sensitivity, a more definitive diagnostic test is required. Abdominal CT is the most appropriate test, given the patient’s localized flank pain, microscopic hematuria, and persistent tachycardia.

Children are more likely than adults to sustain kidney injuries because a child’s kidneys are larger and more lobulated (and therefore less well protected), allowing for easier parenchymal disruption.

Abdominal CT does not definitively diagnose bladder injury, but the suspicion for bladder injury in this patient is low.

Key learning point: The test most likely to yield a definitive diagnosis in a child who complains of flank pain and has microscopic hematuria after sustaining an intra-abdominal injury is CT of the abdomen.

D) INCORRECT:

Select laboratory data, including aspartate aminotransferase and hematocrit, may be helpful for screening after intra-abdominal injury (to better target the need for diagnostic imaging). However, for a patient with tachycardia, focal abdominal tenderness, microscopic hematuria, and negative FAST results, abdominal CT is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with a splenic injury generally have left shoulder pain in addition to left abdominal pain. If a FAST result is negative, abdominal CT would be needed to provide a more definitive diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy presents with a one-day history of red-colored urine, nonspecific abdominal pain, and discomfort with urination. He has not had fever, vomiting, or diarrhea.
His vital signs are normal. During examination, he is obviously uncomfortable and has diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation, which is worse on the left side.
Urinalysis reveals 3+ blood, 2+ protein, a specific gravity of 1.015 (reference range, 1.001–1.035), and a pH of 7.0 (5.0–9.0). Results are negative for white cells, nitrites, ketones, and glucose. Urine microscopy shows >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2).
Additional laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
139
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.7
3.4–4.7


Chloride (mEq/liter)
108
97–107


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
22
22–26


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
16
5–18


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.6
0.3–0.7


Glucose (mg/dL)
98
60–100


What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urine culture can help identify urinary tract infection but is unlikely to be informative in a patient whose urinalysis is negative for white cells or nitrites.

B) INCORRECT:

A urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio can be used to screen for hypercalciuria in children, but this test would only be performed once a stone has been identified and the hematuria has resolved.

C) CORRECT:

Macroscopic hematuria is relatively uncommon in children. If the patient has diffuse abdominal pain (as in this case), nephrolithiasis should lead the differential diagnosis; other possible etiologies include urinary tract infection, trauma, urethral or perineal irritation, and tumor. The absence of pain would broaden the differential diagnosis to include glomerular disease, viral cystitis, and inherited diseases such as Alport syndrome, polycystic kidney disease, and sickle cell disease.

Macroscopic hematuria of glomerular origin is typically described as brown, tea-colored, or cola-colored, whereas macroscopic hematuria from the lower urinary tract is usually pink or red. Macroscopic hematuria in the absence of significant proteinuria or red-cell casts (which are typical of glomerular disease) is an indication for a renal and bladder ultrasound.

Renal ultrasound can help identify specific causes of hematuria. Although it is not as sensitive as CT for the identification of stones, it is the preferred imaging modality in children because of concerns about radiation exposure. Ultrasound can also identify other renal and bladder pathologies, such as obstruction, tumors, and structural urogenital abnormalities.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in evaluating a school-age child with painful gross red hematuria is renal ultrasound.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
β-hCG: beta-human chorionic gonadotropin
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
HPF: high-power field
RBC: red blood cell
UA: urinalysis
US: ultrasound
UTI: urinary tract infection

D) INCORRECT:

Complement levels can distinguish among different forms of glomerulonephritis, but these typically manifest with painless rather than painful hematuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis would identify sickle cell trait, a rare cause of gross hematuria, but it would not be part of the initial evaluation.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents for a sports physical to play baseball. He does not report any symptoms or concerns. His parents report that he had an abnormal urinalysis several years ago, but there is no record of this. His medical history is otherwise unremarkable. His blood pressure and physical examination are normal.
A urine dipstick test in the office shows 2+ blood, a pH of 6.0 (reference range, 5.0–9.0), and a specific gravity of 1.020 (1.001–1.035). A more formal laboratory urinalysis is obtained on the same specimen, and the results remain unchanged. Microscopy reveals 5 to 10 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this child's evaluation?

choices.text: Measure serum creatinine and albumin levels
Repeat urinalysis with microscopy within 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scheduling a kidney ultrasound would be appropriate if structural abnormalities such as stones, cysts, and tumors were suspected. However, these conditions are rarely associated with microscopic hematuria in asymptomatic children. In contrast, many adults with microscopic hematuria undergo cystoscopy to rule out bladder pathology.

B) INCORRECT:

A urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is used to screen for hypercalciuria; this may be appropriate if microscopic hematuria persists on repeat urinalysis with microscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Referring for cystoscopy would be appropriate if structural abnormalities such as stones, cysts, and tumors were suspected. However, these conditions are rarely associated with microscopic hematuria in asymptomatic children. In contrast, many adults with microscopic hematuria undergo cystoscopy to rule out bladder pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum creatinine and albumin levels would be appropriate if hematuria persists and proteinuria is also present, as these findings signal an increased risk for kidney disease. Additional next steps include determination of protein excretion. Referral to a pediatric nephrologist, and possibly kidney biopsy, may be necessary to clarify the diagnosis if there is persistent hematuria and proteinuria.

E) CORRECT:

Most asymptomatic children with microscopic hematuria on screening urinalysis do not have kidney disease. Two large studies of screening urinalyses in asymptomatic children demonstrated that hematuria resolved with observation alone in approximately two-thirds of children.

Although screening urinalysis is not recommended for healthy children without a family history of kidney disease, many children have had a urinalysis for some other reason, and some clinicians continue to obtain screening urinalyses. The recommended next step in evaluating a child with microscopic hematuria identified on screening urinalysis is to repeat the urinalysis with microscopy two to three times over 2 to 3 weeks. If subsequent testing is negative, no further evaluation is necessary.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in evaluating a healthy teenager with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria identified on a urinalysis is to repeat urinalysis with microscopy within 1 to 2 weeks.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine well-child check. He has no complaints and no significant past medical history. He denies dysuria, flank pain, or changes in urine output, and has no history of recent strenuous exercise or trauma. Physical examination is normal. Laboratory results from a random urine sample show microscopic hematuria with 6 to 8 RBCs per high-power field. Serum creatinine is 52 µmol/L (reference range: 27–62 µmol/L) and serum electrolytes are within normal limits.

Blood pressure
100/65 mm Hg

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis
Follow-up microscopic urinalysis on a separate day

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Computed tomography (CT) is used for structural abnormalities or suspected malignancy. This asymptomatic child with normal examination and no systemic signs suggests incidental microscopic hematuria. CT involves radiation exposure, making it unsuitable as a first-line investigation in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum complement levels are assessed in suspected immune-mediated glomerulonephritis, which presents with symptoms like edema, hypertension, or proteinuria. This patient has isolated microscopic hematuria without systemic symptoms or abnormal kidney function, making complement level assessment unnecessary.

C) CORRECT:

In an asymptomatic child with incidental microscopic hematuria, it is important to determine if the hematuria is persistent. Transient hematuria can occur due to benign factors like mild exertion or dehydration. A follow-up urinalysis on a separate day helps confirm persistence and avoids unnecessary invasive investigations. This approach aligns with pediatric guidelines, which recommend confirming persistent abnormalities before further testing. If hematuria persists, further evaluation for renal pathology may be warranted.

Key learning point: In children with asymptomatic hematuria, the initial evaluation should include repeating the urinalysis to confirm persistence before considering more invasive investigations.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is used to investigate suspected lower urinary tract pathology, such as tumors or anatomical abnormalities. This asymptomatic child with isolated microscopic hematuria lacks clinical evidence of bladder or urethral pathology, making cystoscopy inappropriate.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of tea-colored urine. He denies dysuria, urinary frequency, or flank pain. He had pharyngitis 3 weeks ago, which was treated empirically with amoxicillin. Physical examination shows mild periorbital edema and blood pressure of 150/92 mm Hg. Urinalysis shows 20 RBCs per HPF with dysmorphic red blood cells and red blood cell casts. Proteinuria is 2+, and no crystals are present. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Check serum creatinine and complement levels
Obtain urine culture and start empiric antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While the patient has mild edema and hypertension, loop diuretics are not the immediate next step. Confirmation of suspected glomerulonephritis and renal function assessment must be done first.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is used to evaluate the lower urinary tract for nonglomerular causes of hematuria. The presence of RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs suggests glomerular disease, requiring different evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has glomerular hematuria, evidenced by dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts, and proteinuria following a recent pharyngeal infection, raising concern for poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Checking renal function and complement levels is appropriate to evaluate for postinfectious glomerulonephritis and guide further nephrology management. In addition, antibody titers (e.g., antistreptolysin O antibody) should be obtained to confirm a preceding streptococcal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

CT urography may be indicated for nonglomerular hematuria to evaluate for causes such as urinary tract malignancy, but this patient's microscopic findings of dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts suggest glomerular pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Urine culture and antibiotics are appropriate for suspected urinary tract infection. This patient's clinical presentation with dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts, and proteinuria suggests glomerular hematuria rather than urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of osteoarthritis presents with gross hematuria and left flank pain for 6 hours. He reports nausea but denies fever or dysuria. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows mild left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 25 red blood cells per high-power field with normal morphology, no proteinuria, and no casts. Point-of-care ultrasound shows nondistended urinary bladder and mild left hydronephrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Insert urethral catheter and perform bladder irrigation
Obtain CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Obtain CT abdomen and pelvis without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bladder irrigation is indicated for clot retention causing urinary obstruction. While this patient has gross hematuria, no evidence of bladder distension or inability to void suggests clot retention as the primary problem.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) is rarely indicated for the evaluation of suspected ureteral obstruction, as CT is broadly available. IVP is more time-consuming than CT and cannot be used to rule out other diagnoses.

C) INCORRECT:

While ultrasound is 100% sensitive and 90% specific for ureteral obstruction in patients with acute flank pain, it has overall lower sensitivity than CT for detecting stones. Point-of-care ultrasound has already identified hydronephrosis in this patient. Formal ultrasound is appropriate for patients in whom radiation exposure should be minimized, but this patient with gross hematuria and hydronephrosis requires CT imaging to definitively identify stone location, size, and degree of obstruction to guide management decisions.

D) INCORRECT:

While IV contrast may help differentiate ureteral stones from phleboliths and detect alternative causes of abdominal pain, it has reduced sensitivity for kidney stones (approx. 80%) compared to CT without contrast (> 95%). CT with contrast is therefore not the preferred imaging modality in a patient with suspected nephrolithiasis based on clinical presentation and hydronephrosis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with gross hematuria, flank pain, and hydronephrosis, suggesting nephrolithiasis with potential obstruction. CT abdomen and pelvis without contrast is the appropriate next step to evaluate stone location, size, degree of obstruction, and complications such as perinephric fat stranding. Imaging results guide further management decisions, including need for urgent urology consultation.
